intro.name: Ruby Chen
intro.intro: An explorer passionate about learning new skills, with a strong focus on communication, collaboration, and organization.

aboutMe.description:
Hi! I am Ruby Yi Tzu Chen, you can call me Ruby :)

My passion for design and development has led me through roles such as interaction designer, visual marketing designer, front-end developer, and currently, website operations specialist. Iâ€™m curious, always eager to learn, and excited about the future and my continued growth.

educations.description: Completed several websites as a front-end developer, API integrator, and project coordinator.

project.title: Bridging Humans and the Ocean
project.description: An immersive exhibition exploring the human-coral relationship.
project.longDescription: This is one of my previous designer works, my role includes designing display panels, interactive game UI, and assisting in game planning, animation design, exhibition shooting, and video editing.
project.brainStormingDescription: We started by creating the poster, followed by the main visual for the entire exhibition. We learned that the project would focus on the relationship between coral and humans, so sea colors were naturally incorporated.
project.makingDescription:
We were fascinated by the story of corals and people, which inspired us to design an immersive, interactive, ocean-themed exhibit. I used these tools to complete this amazing exhibition design journey: Adobe Illustrator, Photoshop, Premiere Pro, After Effects, and Unity2D.

Through team collaboration, we produced all the interactive elements in just six months. The process began with designing on the computer, and after extensive discussions with the client, we moved to the exhibit site to continue our work. Transforming the exhibit from raw materials to a lively interactive project was truly a magnificent experience.
project.outComeDescription:
The exhibit features a highly realistic underwater coral reef entrance simulation, followed by an interactive table with models of several coral species introducing themselves, a half-projected wall showing the coral farming process, a full interactive wall explaining the ROV, and last but not least, the deep-sea multimedia room.

At the start of the exhibition, you'll enter a light blue sea area, and as you move deeper into the exhibit, the space gradually becomes darker with each step, eventually leading you to the deep-sea area. This immersive interactive experience will help you better understand the relationship between coral and humans, allowing you to explore all the marvelous details and refresh your knowledge about them.
project.longTitle: Bridging Humans and the Ocean - Dive into Coral Reefs

project.title: Simple Twitter
project.description: As the name suggests, it's an easier version of Twitter.
project.longDescription: This project is the final project of Alpha Camp online web development boot camp. It helped me gain a comprehensive understanding of web development.
project.brainStormingDescription: This is the first project I started as a front-end developer. I learned by going through persona research, following the roadmap to becoming a front-end developer, and using an efficient to-do list with my teammates, which consisted of two front-end developers and two back-end developers in total.
project.makingDescription:
It took us a whole month to create this lightweight website. I gained experience in project management and used the following tools: ReactJS, Bootstrap CSS, CSS Modules, Git, and API integration.

We divided the work into creating separate components and researching API connections. Thanks to the collaboration of my front-end teammate, we successfully completed the project ahead of schedule.
project.outComeDescription:
On Simple Twitter, you need to log in to the site, after which you can tweet, write a tweet, like a tweet, and edit a tweet. You can also manage users and tweets through the admin page.

Additionally, there are various alerts on the site to ensure you don't exceed the word limit, choose an already taken user ID, and more. Due to the backend data being unreachable, this site cannot be accessed right now. However, you can still watch the video to see how it goes.
project.longTitle: Simple Twitter - Alpha Camp Final Project

credits.title: My Role
credits.subTitle: Frontend Developer /  API Integrator / Project Coordinator

project.title: LaBar Game
project.longDescription: A simple slot machine game created for the purpose of drawing a lucky red envelope given after the Lunar New Year holiday when work resumes. This event has ended, so the website link is no longer functional.
project.brainStormingDescription: We created this little game simply because it's the easiest way to have some fun and also let the boss randomly choose who will receive the amount of money.
project.makingDescription: The designer quickly created a visual design, and I followed up on her work using plain HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, with animation controlled by jQuery.
project.outComeDescription: Simply click the lever of the slot machine, and you will see three icons on the screen. The combination of these icons will determine the final prize you will receive. The slot machine game ultimately allowed over 15 company employees to each receive a bonus ranging from 200 to 2,000 TWD.

project.title: Store Location Table
project.description: A table used to allow customers to easily find store locations, categorized by region.
project.longDescription: Searching for a store location from an endless list can be daunting. I created an easily categorized list that can be quickly narrowed down to a concise list, showing only one region at a time. I have classified the list according to the major regions of Taiwan, namely "Northern District", "Central District" and "Southern District".
project.brainStormingDescription: I wanted to create a simple table, but the list was too long to fit in a single scroll on the screen. So, I came up with the idea of creating a categorized table.
project.makingDescription: To create the table, I carefully organized the list of store locations and ensured that the Google Map links were in the same format. This is a simple table website built using tools like Tailwind CSS, Next.js, Vercel, and Git.
project.outComeDescription: The final table is categorized by the navbar at the top, which includes "North", "Central", "South", and "All Region". You can click on the desired region you wish to explore, and the table will change accordingly.

project.title: Chill Split
project.description: This is an app made to split friends and family's bill. You can easily split it during a trip or a monthly spending conclusion.
project.longDescription: A bill splitting app project proudly made by three partners, a front-end, a back-end and a designer.It is also made with the LINE Front-end Framework (LIFF) app, making it easy for anyone registered with Line to use.
project.brainStormingDescription: We first decided on a name for the app, then updated the prototype and conducted weekly research. Everything is documented in Notion, from the initial sketch of the plan to the final meeting minutes.
project.makingDescription:
As the front-end developer on the team, I play a crucial role as a bridge between the other two members. Whether it's discussing slight animations for the user interface or how the APIs should be handed off, we spend a significant amount of time ensuring everything works as smoothly and precisely as it should.

I completed it using the Next.js framework, CSS tools like Tailwind CSS, and animation tools like Motion (formerly known as Framer Motion). I also used Git for team collaboration and integrated APIs by simulating with json-server and connecting to actual APIs with the help of tools like Apidog. The calculator was created thanks to Stack Overflow users who helped me solve countless problems.
project.outComeDescription: The result of "Chill Split" may not be perfect, but it's a great kickstart for my career transition. I collaborated with an excellent UI/UX designer and a dedicated backend developer. We made the app capable of splitting costs in TWD, categorizing expenses, grouping by date, adding notes, adding members, allowing different amounts for the same expense, and editing all the features mentioned above, among others.
